posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: My VH-109 radio wasn't supporting Wi-Fi after competition. We reconfigured it to old settings, but it still wouldn't support Wi-Fi. Installing new firmware and reconfiguring repeatedly didn't resolve the issue either. Trying another brand-new VH-109 and reconfiguring it made no difference. After attempting to reinstall the firmware, it still failed. The robot functionsed when connected via Ethernet to the Driver Station port but couldn't establish a Wi-Fi connection. I'm at a loss for what else to tryâ€”I'm really stuck.

posts.name: Ryan Radtke
posts.cooked: Are you trying to connect via 2.4Ghz?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
dip switch?  

To clarify in case OP isnâ€™t aware the VH-109 has three switches on the back one of which enables the 2.4GHz WiFi This is generally recommended to be turned off at competitions but can be useful to turn on when running the robot at home If you donâ€™t have a 2.4GHz light showing up on the front of the radio this is VERY likely the reason why  

Please note that the other two switches toggle the Passive PoE functionality on the radio and if you turn this feature on while an incompatible device is connected you can fry the device so make sure youâ€™re getting the right switch  

DIP Switch Reference: https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/overview/wiring-your-radio#power-over-ethernet-poe-for-downstream-devices Status light Reference: https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/overview/led-status-indications

posts.name: Andrew McBride
posts.cooked: To add additional context, since you mentioned having 2 VH-109, you may want to set them up to run on 6GHz to ensure more consistent wireless connection. You can find documentation on that here.

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked: Especially important: Contact WCP customer service at support@wcproducts.com if you still canâ€™t get it to work. One of our teamâ€™s radios suddenly bootlooped, and the customer service agent remote in to my computer and fixed it successfully.
